channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Luxury Brands Have a Strict Hierarchy. Burberry Found Out the Hard Way.
item.description: The British label’s seven-year push to attract wealthier shoppers has failed and left it with a threadbare share price.

item.title: Mortgage rates fall, but buyer demand drops to 6-month low
item.description: Mortgage applications fell 10.1% in the last week, the Mortgage Bankers Association said.

item.title: Schwab Wants to Fix Its Struggling Bank. Investors Are Skeptical.
item.description: Roughly half of the brokerage’s revenue comes from banking.

item.title: Vector Group’s stock up 6% on deal to be acquired by Japan’s JT Group in $2.4 billion tobacco deal
item.description: JT, which makes and sells some of the best-known cigarette brands — including Winston and Camel outside the U.S. — will pay $15 a share in cash, equal to a 29.9% premium over Vector’s 60-day volume-weighted average share price.

item.title: Texas Instruments Tries to Ease Its Capital Pain
item.description: The chip maker says it might moderate capital spending in 2026 amid activist pressure, but new cash flow targets also hinge on revenue pulling out of an extended slump.

item.title: This S&P 500 hot streak is actually a warning sign for your stocks
item.description: 15 consecutive quarters of revenue growth for S&P 500 companies — not enough to support current prices.

item.title: As Generation X Approaches Retirement, Reality Still Bites
item.description: The ‘forgotten generation,’ born between 1965 and 1980, launched their careers at the start of a massive shift in how Americans work.

item.title: U.K. competition watchdog drop probes into Google and Apple app stores
item.description: The Competition and Markets Authority said it plans to use new powers given to it in May to address its concerns about abuses of Google and Apple’s dominant market positions

item.title: How to Plan for Retirement if You're Behind on Saving in Middle Age
item.description: Many financial advisers say people in their 40s and 50s still have time to increase their savings rate and develop a road map for their later years.

item.title: It’s not just stocks — there’s another market reaching into thin air, this banking giant says
item.description: The euro has been on a roll even as European data has been underwhelming.
